description.excerpt: Halyard is an extremely horizontally scalable triple store with support for named graphs, designed for integration of extremely large semantic data models and for storage and SPARQL 1.1 querying of complete Linked Data universe snapshots. Halyard implementation is based on Eclipse RDF4J framework and Apache HBase database, and it is completely written in Java.
common - a library for direct mapping between an RDF data model and Apache HBase

sail - an implementation of the RDF4J Storage and Inference Layer on top of Apache HBase 
tools - a set of command line and Apache Hadoop MapReduce tools for loading, updating, querying, and exporting the data with maximum performance

Halyard is an extremely horizontally scalable Triplestore with support for Named Graphs, designed for integration of extremely large Semantic Data Models, and for storage and SPARQL 1.1 querying of the whole Linked Data universe snapshots.

excerpt.body:
Halyard 2.5 ("Prague") release supports legacy HBase 1.x clusters, while Halyard 3.2 ("Senohraby") release is targeted to support the newest HBase 2.x systems (including Hadoop 3 distributions).
Both releases are bringing the same improvements and bug-fixes.
The only major change is update of the underlying Eclipse RDF4J framework from version 2.5.1 to version 3.0.3. For the impact on Halyard check [Eclipse RDF4J release notes](https://rdf4j.org/release-notes/).
excerpt.name: Halyard 3.2 ("Senohraby")

excerpt.body:
Halyard 2.4 ("Karlsruhe") release supports legacy HBase 1.x clusters, while Halyard 3.1 ("Fächerstadt") release is targeted to support the newest HBase 2.x systems (including Hadoop 3 distributions).
Both releases are bringing the same improvements and bug-fixes. 
Majority of the never-ending work has been done on the [HalyardQueryJoinOptimizer](https://github.com/Merck/Halyard/blob/master/strategy/src/main/java/com/msd/gin/halyard/optimizers/HalyardQueryJoinOptimizer.java) and its cooperation with [halyard:search](https://merck.github.io/Halyard/ns#search) and [halyard:forkAndFilterBy](http://merck.github.io/Halyard/ns#forkAndFilterBy) features.
Unfortunately some of the promising improvements failed and had to be reverted due to negative effects. 
Multiple issues have been fixed on [Halyard Strategy](https://github.com/Merck/Halyard/tree/master/strategy/src/main/java/com/msd/gin/halyard/strategy), [HBase Sail](https://github.com/Merck/Halyard/blob/master/sail/src/main/java/com/msd/gin/halyard/sail/HBaseSail.java), and [Halyard Endpoint](https://github.com/Merck/Halyard/blob/master/tools/src/main/java/com/msd/gin/halyard/tools/HttpSparqlHandler.java) components.
excerpt.name: Halyard 3.1 ("Fächerstadt")

excerpt.body:
Halyard 3.0 release is a part of double-release together with Halyard 2.3.
Purpose of version 3.0 release is to support the newest HBase 2.x systems (including Hadoop 3 distributions), while release 2.3 is targeted to the legacy HBase 1.x clusters. 
Main new feature (beside the HBase 2 support) is new central [HBaseRepositoryManager](https://github.com/Merck/Halyard/blob/dev-hbase2/sail/src/main/java/com/msd/gin/halyard/sail/HBaseRepositoryManager.java) for RDF4J Server, which allows to spawn a battery of RDF4J Servers across the cluster and manage their repositories configuration centrally.
Important is also upgrade of RDF4J to version 2.5.1, and several minor fixes of Halyard Endpoint and Halyard Bulk Update tools.
excerpt.name: Halyard 3.0 ("Piran")

excerpt.body:
Halyard 2.3 release is a part of double-release together with Halyard 3.0.
Purpose of version 2.3 release is to continue support of legacy HBase 1.x systems, while release 3.0 is targeted to the latest HBase 2.x clusters. 
Main new feature is new central [HBaseRepositoryManager](https://github.com/Merck/Halyard/blob/master/sail/src/main/java/com/msd/gin/halyard/sail/HBaseRepositoryManager.java) for RDF4J Server, which allows to spawn a battery of RDF4J Servers across the cluster and manage their repositories configuration centrally.
Important is also upgrade of RDF4J to version 2.5.1, and several minor fixes of Halyard Endpoint and Halyard Bulk Update tools.
excerpt.name: Halyard 2.3 ("Portoroz")

excerpt.body:
Halyard 2.2 release brings several new tools, improvements and bugfixes.
One of the newly introduced tools is [Halyard Endpoint](https://merck.github.io/Halyard/tools.html#halyard-endpoint), which may help you to instantly setup a read-only SPARQL endpoint from command line on any of your cluster node, with optional custom API configuration that translates into pre-configured SPARQL query calls.
Another new experimental MapReduce tool is is [Halyard Summary](https://merck.github.io/Halyard/tools.html#halyard-summary), it calculates RDF summary of a dataset in a form of self-described synthetic RDF schema with cardinality attributes. Halyard Summary does not have yet any fancy peer UI application to present the summary, however even raw summary data might be helpful in certain situations.
From the various improvements and bugfixes I would highlight RDF4J updated to version 2.4.1, improvements in ElasticSearch Indexer, fixes in bindings handling in [Halyard Federated Queries](https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/inside-halyard-5-sparql-federation-without-border-controls-sotona), better handling of namespaces during Bulk Load, fixed handling of Sesame.NIL constant according to the RDF4J standard, and several fixes in documentation.
excerpt.name: Halyard 2.2 ("Philadelphia")

excerpt.body:
Halyard 2.1 is mainly bug-fixing release with many new tests added.
There are several important fixes in [Halyard Strategy](
https://github.com/Merck/Halyard/tree/master/strategy/src/main/java/com/msd/gin/halyard/strategy), in [SPARQL Optimizers](
https://github.com/Merck/Halyard/tree/master/strategy/src/main/java/com/msd/gin/halyard/optimizers), [Cardinality Calculator](https://github.com/Merck/Halyard/blob/master/sail/src/main/java/com/msd/gin/halyard/sail/HalyardStatsBasedStatementPatternCardinalityCalculator.java), and bundled [RDF4J Workbench](http://docs.rdf4j.org/server-workbench-console/).
Major focus was to enable smooth run of [Halyard Federated Queries](
https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/inside-halyard-5-sparql-federation-without-border-controls-sotona), complex [Bulk Export](https://merck.github.io/Halyard/tools.html#halyard-bulk-export) and [Bulk Update](https://merck.github.io/Halyard/tools.html#halyard-bulk-update) queries, and queries combining SPARQL with [ElasticSearch support](https://merck.github.io/Halyard/usage.html#cooperation-with-elasticsearch).
Last but not least - [Halyard ElasticSearch Indexer](https://merck.github.io/Halyard/tools.html#halyard-elasticsearch-index) has new feature to restrict indexation to just one specified named graph.
excerpt.name: Halyard 2.1 ("Heathrow")

excerpt.body:
Major focus of Halyard 2.0 release is on usability.
All the Halyard command line tools have been consolidated under [one launcher](https://merck.github.io/Halyard/tools.html#halyard) and almost all of them have been improved. New SPARQL function [halyard:forkAndFilterBy](https://merck.github.io/Halyard/ns.html#custom-sparql-filter-functions) is unifying parallelization approach of [Halyard Bulk Update](https://merck.github.io/Halyard/tools.html#halyard-bulk-update-) and [Bulk Export](https://merck.github.io/Halyard/tools.html#halyard-bulk-export-) tools. [Halyard ElasticSearch](https://merck.github.io/Halyard/usage.html#cooperation-with-elasticsearch) integration newly propagates results back to the SPARQL query variables and [Halyard ElasticSearch Indexer](https://merck.github.io/Halyard/tools.html#halyard-elasticsearch-index-) allows to create the index mapping. Parsing of partially corrupted or invalid Turtle files is now more robust to [Bulk Load](https://merck.github.io/Halyard/tools.html#halyard-bulk-load) maximum data also from "dirty" datasets (in --skip-invalid mode). Performance of the [Halyard-internal SPARQL federation](https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/inside-halyard-5-sparql-federation-without-border-controls-sotona/) has been improved by including federated cardinalities in the [query optimisation](https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/inside-halyard-6-statistics-based-acceleration-sparql-adam-sotona/). And last but not least - new [Halyard command line profiler tool](https://merck.github.io/Halyard/tools.html#halyard-profile) reports SPARQL query optimizers data to help further offline performance analysis.
excerpt.name: Halyard 2.0 ("Main Station")

excerpt.body:
The biggest changes in Halyard 1.5 release are within its tooling. 
HalyardBulkUpdate now support more complex configuration, it supports deletion of statements, and multi-stage SPARQL Update sequences.
New tools HalyardBulkExport and HalyardBulkDelete have been introduced.
HalyardElasticIndexer has been improved and more documentation about Halyard cooperation with ElasticSearch has been added.
Significant performance improvements for datasets with zillion of named graphs include: de-duplication of triples in default graph context, fixes in CardinalityCalculator, and improved HalyardStats generation.
Last but not least - underlying RDF4J has been updated to version 2.3.2
excerpt.name: Halyard 1.5 ("Lipno")

excerpt.body:
Halyard 1.4 release fixes several bugs, for example:
SPARQL queries containing optional sub-selects are now fully compliant with the specification .  
Property paths in SPARQL queries should no more cause random performance problems. 
And SAIL now response correctly on some no-standard situations.
Underlying RDF4J framework has been upgraded to version 2.2.4 and all the Halyard Strategy compliance tests are now simulating latency to better simulate and catch various asynchronous race conditions.
Default Halyard properties has been a bit adjusted and extended improve performance with respect to the latest measurements.
And at last but not least a new Halyard library module with RDF4J RIO extensions has been introduced to support various new formats. 
Initially there are NDJSONLDParser as a new-line-delimited extension of JSONLDParser, and JSONParser providing an experimental synthetic mapping from general JSON file into RDF.
excerpt.name: Halyard 1.4 ("Newark")

excerpt.body:
Halyard 1.3 release contains several bug-fixes and new tools and feature. Halyard HBase SAIL newly cooperates with supplementary ElasticSearch for advanced text search capabilities over the stored literals. Halyard Bulk Update tool newly supports SPARQL Delete/Insert queries. Halyard Bulk load supports loading from locally provided Hadoop filesystems (for example Amazon S3 or Google GFS). New time-aware HBase SAIL has been introduced with basic support in several Halyard tools to open doors for time-aware graph operations.

You can find it in the documentation here: https://merck.github.io/Halyard/

Thank you,
Adam Sotona
excerpt.name: Halyard 1.3 ("Vienna")

excerpt.body:
Halyard 1.2 release contains several bug-fixes and improvements. Statistical tool is improved and it generates more advanced statistics. Performance of the SPARQL query evaluation is improved by re-ordering of joins based on the actual statistics. Bulk load performance has been improved for large number of source RDF files.  New pre-split calculator creates optimal HBase table region splits for fast and smooth bulk load process of very large datasets.

You can find it in the documentation here: https://merck.github.io/Halyard/

Thank you,
Adam Sotona
excerpt.name: Halyard 1.2 ("Under Attack")

excerpt.body:
Halyard 1.1 release contains several bug-fixes and improvements, new statistical tool, new support for cross-datasets queries using SPARQL SERVICE, and new documentation with more tutorials.

Check for documentation here: https://merck.github.io/Halyard/

Enjoy,
Adam Sotona
excerpt.name: Halyard 1.1 ("Spring")

excerpt.body:
This is an initial Halyard release so everything is new in the release notes.

Check for documentation here: https://merck.github.io/Halyard/

Feel free to add your feedback, comments and suggestions under [Issues](https://github.com/Merck/Halyard/issues).

Thank you,
Adam
excerpt.name: Halyard 1.0 ("Not In December")

usage.excerpt:
[Download](https://github.com/Merck/Halyard/releases) and unzip the latest `halyard-sdk-<version>.zip` bundle to a Apache Hadoop cluster node with configured Apache HBase client.

Halyard is expected to run on an Apache Hadoop cluster node with configured Apache HBase client. Apache Hadoop and Apache HBase components are not bundled with Halyard. The runtime requirements are:

 * Apache Hadoop version 2.5.1 or higher
 * Apache HBase version 1.1.2 or higher
 * Java 8 Runtime

*Note: Recommended Apache Hadoop distribution is the latest version of Hortonworks Data Platform (HDP) or Amazon Elastic Map Reduce (EMR).*

See [Documentation](https://merck.github.io/Halyard) for usage examples, architecture information, and more.
